sn24.5:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.5:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn24.5:1.3.pli: ‘natthi dinnaṃ, natthi yiṭṭhaṃ, natthi hutaṃ, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko; natthi ayaṃ loko, natthi paro loko, natthi mātā, natthi pitā, natthi sattā opapātikā; natthi loke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sammaggatā sammāpaṭipannā ye imañca lokaṃ parañca lokaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedenti.
sn24.5:1.3.eng: ‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no such thing as mother and father, or beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.
sn24.5:1.3.comm: This nihilist doctrine (natthikavāda) is attributed to Ajita of the Hair Blanket at DN 2:23.2. | The denial of “mother and father” is usually interpreted as the denial of moral duty towards one’s parents. However, I think it is a doctrine of conception which denies that a child is created by the mother and father. Rather, the child is produced by the four elements, with parents as mere instigators and incubators. | Compare Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3.23 on the liberated Self, “A father is not a father, a mother is not a mother, worlds are not worlds, gods are not gods, and Vedas are not Vedas. Here a thief is not a thief, an abortionist is not an abortionist, an outcaste is not an outcaste, a pariah is not a pariah, a recluse is not a recluse, and an ascetic is not an ascetic. Neither the good nor the bad follows him, for he has now passed beyond all sorrows of the heart.”

sn24.5:1.4.pli: Cātumahābhūtiko ayaṃ puriso yadā kālaṃ karoti pathavī pathavīkāyaṃ anupeti anupagacchati, āpo āpokāyaṃ anupeti anupagacchati, tejo tejokāyaṃ anupeti anupagacchati, vāyo vāyokāyaṃ anupeti anupagacchati.
sn24.5:1.4.eng: This person is made up of the four principal states. When they die, the earth in their body progresses and proceeds to the substance of earth. The water in their body progresses and proceeds to the substance of water. The fire in their body progresses and proceeds to the substance of fire. The air in their body progresses and proceeds to the substance of air.

sn24.5:1.5.eng: The faculties are transferred to space.

sn24.5:1.6.eng: Four men with a bier carry away the corpse.

sn24.5:1.7.eng: Their footprints show the way to the cremation ground.

sn24.5:1.9.eng: Offerings dedicated to the gods end in ashes.

sn24.5:1.10.eng: Giving is a doctrine of morons.
sn24.5:1.10.comm: Dattu is a rare term for “idiot” or “moron”, only spoken by sectarian teachers, so should probably be distinguished from the Buddhist “fool”.

sn24.5:1.11.pli: Tesaṃ tucchaṃ musā vilāpo ye keci atthikavādaṃ vadanti.
sn24.5:1.11.eng: When anyone affirms a positive teaching it’s just baseless, false nonsense.

sn24.5:1.12.eng: Both the foolish and the astute are annihilated and destroyed when their body breaks up, and don’t exist after death’?”

sn24.6:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.6:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn24.6:1.3.pli: ‘karoto kārayato chindato chedāpayato pacato pācāpayato socato socāpayato kilamato kilamāpayato phandato phandāpayato pāṇamatipātayato adinnaṃ ādiyato sandhiṃ chindato nillopaṃ harato ekāgārikaṃ karoto paripanthe tiṭṭhato paradāraṃ gacchato musā bhaṇato karoto na karīyati pāpaṃ.
sn24.6:1.3.eng: ‘The one who acts does nothing wrong when they punish, mutilate, torture, aggrieve, oppress, intimidate, or when they encourage others to do the same. Nothing bad is done when they kill, steal, break into houses, plunder wealth, steal from isolated buildings, commit highway robbery, commit adultery, and lie.
sn24.6:1.3.comm: The doctrine of inefficacy of action (akiriyavāda), which is attributed to Pūraṇa Kassapa at DN 2:17.2.

sn24.6:1.4.pli: Khurapariyantena cepi cakkena yo imissā pathaviyā pāṇe ekamaṃsakhalaṃ ekamaṃsapuñjaṃ kareyya, natthi tatonidānaṃ pāpaṃ, natthi pāpassa āgamo.
sn24.6:1.4.eng: If you were to reduce all the living creatures of this earth to one heap and mass of flesh with a razor-edged chakram, no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil.

sn24.6:1.5.pli: Dakkhiṇañcepi gaṅgāya tīraṃ gaccheyya; hananto ghātento chindanto chedāpento pacanto pācento, natthi tatonidānaṃ pāpaṃ, natthi pāpassa āgamo.
sn24.6:1.5.eng: If you were to go along the south bank of the Ganges killing, mutilating, and torturing, and encouraging others to do the same, no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil.

sn24.6:1.6.pli: Uttarañcepi gaṅgāya tīraṃ gaccheyya; dadanto dāpento yajanto yajāpento, natthi tatonidānaṃ puññaṃ, natthi puññassa āgamo.
sn24.6:1.6.eng: If you were to go along the north bank of the Ganges giving and sacrificing and encouraging others to do the same, no merit comes of that, and no outcome of merit.

sn24.6:1.7.pli: Dānena damena saṃyamena saccavajjena natthi puññaṃ natthi puññassa āgamo’”ti.
sn24.6:1.7.eng: In giving, self-control, restraint, and truthfulness there is no merit or outcome of merit’?”

sn24.6:1.8.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn24.6:2.2.eng: ‘The one who acts does nothing wrong …

sn24.7:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.7:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn24.7:1.3.eng: ‘There is no cause or reason for the corruption of sentient beings.
sn24.7:1.3.comm: Makkhali Gosāla’s doctrine of no-cause (ahetukavāda), see SN 22.60:2.2, DN 2:20.2.

sn24.7:1.4.eng: Sentient beings are corrupted without cause or reason.

sn24.7:1.5.pli: Natthi hetu, natthi paccayo sattānaṃ visuddhiyā.
sn24.7:1.5.eng: There’s no cause or reason for the purification of sentient beings.

sn24.7:1.6.eng: Sentient beings are purified without cause or reason.

sn24.7:1.7.pli: Natthi balaṃ natthi vīriyaṃ natthi purisathāmo natthi purisaparakkamo.
sn24.7:1.7.eng: There is no power, no energy, no human strength or vigor.

sn24.7:1.8.pli: Sabbe sattā sabbe pāṇā sabbe bhūtā sabbe jīvā avasā abalā avīriyā niyatisaṅgatibhāvapariṇatā chasvevābhijātīsu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedentī’”ti?
sn24.7:1.8.eng: All sentient beings, all living creatures, all beings, all souls lack control, power, and energy. Molded by destiny, circumstance, and nature, they experience pleasure and pain in the six classes of rebirth’?”

sn24.7:1.9.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn24.70:0.3.eng: The Self Is Neither Happy Nor Suffering

sn24.70:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.70:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn24.70:1.3.eng: ‘The self is neither happy nor suffering, and healthy after death’?”

sn24.70:1.4.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn24.70:2.1.eng: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:

sn24.70:2.2.eng: ‘The self is neither happy nor suffering, and is healthy after death.’

sn24.70:2.6.eng: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:

sn24.70:2.7.eng: ‘The self is neither happy nor suffering, and healthy after death.’

sn24.70:3.8.pli: Tasmiṃ sati, tadupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.70:3.8.eng: When this exists, grasping at this, the view arises:

sn24.70:3.9.eng: ‘The self is neither happy nor suffering, and is healthy after death.’

sn24.70:3.19.eng: When this exists, grasping at this, the view arises:

sn24.70:3.20.eng: ‘The self is neither happy nor suffering, and healthy after death.’”

sn24.71:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.71:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn24.71:1.3.pli: ‘na vātā vāyanti, na najjo sandanti, na gabbhiniyo vijāyanti, na candimasūriyā udenti vā apenti vā esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā’”ti?
sn24.71:1.3.eng: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar’?”

sn24.71:1.4.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn24.71:2.1.pli: “Rūpe kho, bhikkhave, sati, rūpaṃ upādāya, rūpaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.71:2.1.eng: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:

sn24.71:2.2.eng: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’

sn24.71:2.6.pli: viññāṇe sati, viññāṇaṃ upādāya, viññāṇaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.71:2.6.eng: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:

sn24.71:2.7.eng: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’

sn24.71:2.11.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn24.71:2.11.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn24.71:2.13.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn24.71:2.13.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn24.71:2.14.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn24.71:2.21.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn24.71:2.21.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn24.71:2.23.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn24.71:2.23.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn24.71:2.24.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn24.71:3.1.pli: “Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, yaṃ kiñci rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā, oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ rūpaṃ: ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn24.71:3.1.eng: “So you should truly see any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn24.71:3.2.eng: You should truly see any kind of feeling …

sn24.71:3.5.pli: yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ viññāṇaṃ: ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn24.71:3.5.eng: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn24.71:4.2.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn24.72-95:1.1.eng: (Tell in full as in the 24 discourses of the second chapter.)

sn24.8:1.1.comm: Mahā in the title refers to the length of the view, not to its quality.

sn24.8:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.8:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn24.8:1.3.pli: ‘sattime kāyā akaṭā, akaṭavidhā, animmitā, animmātā, vañjhā, kūṭaṭṭhā, esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā;
sn24.8:1.3.eng: ‘There are these seven substances that are not made, not derived, not created, without a creator, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.
sn24.8:1.3.comm: The doctrine of the seven substances (sattakāyavāda) is attributed to Pakudha Kaccāyana at DN 2:26.2; also at MN 76:16.2. It has clear similarities to the niccavāda of SN 24.1.

sn24.8:1.4.pli: te na iñjanti, na vipariṇamanti, na aññamaññaṃ byābādhenti; nālaṃ aññamaññassa sukhāya vā dukkhāya vā sukhadukkhāya vā.
sn24.8:1.4.eng: They don’t move or deteriorate or obstruct each other. They’re unable to cause pleasure, pain, or both pleasure and pain to each other.

sn24.8:1.6.pli: Pathavīkāyo, āpokāyo, tejokāyo, vāyokāyo, sukhe, dukkhe, jīve sattame.
sn24.8:1.6.eng: The substances of earth, water, fire, air; pleasure, pain, and the soul is the seventh.

sn24.8:1.7.pli: Ime satta kāyā akaṭā, akaṭavidhā, animmitā, animmātā, vañjhā, kūṭaṭṭhā esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā;
sn24.8:1.7.eng: These seven substances are not made, not derived, not created, without a creator, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.

sn24.8:1.8.pli: te na iñjanti, na vipariṇamanti, na aññamaññaṃ byābādhenti; nālaṃ aññamaññassa sukhāya vā dukkhāya vā sukhadukkhāya vā.
sn24.8:1.8.eng: They don’t move or deteriorate or obstruct each other. They’re unable to cause pleasure, pain, or both pleasure and pain to each other.
sn24.8:1.8.comm: Here the versions at DN 2:26.8 and MN 76:16.8 insert another sentence, saying that there is no-one who kills or is killed, etc.

sn24.8:1.9.pli: Yopi tiṇhena satthena sīsaṃ chindati, na sopi kañci jīvitā voropeti;
sn24.8:1.9.eng: If you chop off someone’s head with a sharp sword, you don’t take anyone’s life.

sn24.8:1.10.eng: The sword simply passes through the gap between the seven substances.

sn24.8:1.11.pli: Cuddasa kho panimāni yonipamukhasatasahassāni saṭṭhi ca satāni cha ca satāni pañca ca kammuno satāni pañca ca kammāni, tīṇi ca kammāni, kamme ca aḍḍhakamme ca dvaṭṭhipaṭipadā, dvaṭṭhantarakappā, chaḷābhijātiyo, aṭṭha purisabhūmiyo, ekūnapaññāsa ājīvakasate, ekūnapaññāsa paribbājakasate, ekūnapaññāsa nāgavāsasate, vīse indriyasate, tiṃse nirayasate, chattiṃsarajodhātuyo, satta saññīgabbhā, satta asaññīgabbhā, satta nigaṇṭhigabbhā, satta devā, satta mānusā, satta pesācā, satta sarā, satta pavuṭā, satta papātā, satta ca papātasatāni, satta supinā, satta supinasatāni, cullāsīti mahākappino satasahassāni, yāni bāle ca paṇḍite ca sandhāvitvā saṃsaritvā dukkhassantaṃ karissanti.
sn24.8:1.11.eng: There are 1.4 million main wombs, and 6,000, and 600; 500 deeds, and five, and three; deeds and half-deeds; 62 paths of practice, 62 sub-eons, six classes of rebirth, and eight stages in a person’s life; 4,900 Ājīvaka ascetics, 4,900 wanderers, and 4,900 dragon abodes; 2,000 lordships, 3,000 hells, and 36 realms of dusky sky; seven percipient embryos, seven non-percipient embryos, seven knotless embryos, seven gods, seven mental heavens, seven goblins, seven streams, seven castoff incarnations and 700 castoff incarnations, seven downfalls and 700 downfalls, seven dreams and 700 dreams, and 8.4 million great eons—through all of which the foolish and the astute transmigrate before making an end of suffering.
sn24.8:1.11.comm: At DN 2:20.7 this “doctrine of purification through transmigration” (saṁsārasuddhivāda) is taught by Makkhali Gosāla, but at MN 76:16.11 it is attached to the seven substances view, as here. It seems that Pakudha and Makkhali were fellow-travellers for a time, and it is likely that they shared many overlaps, and the schools may even have merged.

sn24.8:1.12.pli: Tattha natthi imināhaṃ sīlena vā vatena vā tapena vā brahmacariyena vā aparipakkaṃ vā kammaṃ paripācessāmi;
sn24.8:1.12.eng: And here there is no such thing as this: “By this precept or observance or fervent austerity or spiritual life I shall force unripened deeds to bear their fruit, or eliminate old deeds by experiencing their results little by little”—for that cannot be.

sn24.8:1.13.pli: paripakkaṃ vā kammaṃ phussa phussa byantīkarissāmīti hevaṃ natthi doṇamite sukhadukkhe pariyantakate saṃsāre, natthi hāyanavaḍḍhane, natthi ukkaṃsāvakaṃse.
sn24.8:1.13.eng: Pleasure and pain are allotted. Transmigration lasts only for a limited period, so there’s no increase or decrease, no getting better or worse.

sn24.8:1.14.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma suttaguḷe khitte nibbeṭhiyamānameva paleti;
sn24.8:1.14.eng: It’s like how, when you toss a ball of string, it rolls away unraveling.

sn24.8:1.15.pli: evameva bāle ca paṇḍite ca nibbeṭhiyamānā sukhadukkhaṃ palentī’”ti?
sn24.8:1.15.eng: In the same way, after transmigrating the foolish and the astute roll away unraveling as far as pleasure and pain extend’?”
sn24.8:1.15.comm: The reading here (nibbeṭhiyamānā sukhadukkhaṁ palenti) differs from DN 2:20.11 and MN 76:16.15. Sukhadukkhaṁ is the so-called “accusative of extension”, denoting the range to which the verb applies (Wijesekera, Syntax of the Cases, §44).

sn24.8:1.16.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn24.8:2.1.pli: “Rūpe kho, bhikkhave, sati, rūpaṃ upādāya, rūpaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.8:2.1.eng: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:

sn24.8:2.2.eng: ‘There are these seven substances that are not made …

sn24.8:2.3.eng: the foolish and the astute will make an end of suffering.’

sn24.8:2.7.pli: viññāṇe sati, viññāṇaṃ upādāya, viññāṇaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn24.8:2.7.eng: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:

sn24.8:2.8.eng: ‘There are these seven substances that are not made …

sn24.8:2.9.eng: the foolish and the astute will make an end of suffering.’

sn24.8:3.4.pli: “yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:

sn24.8:3.8.pli: “Yampidaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā tampi niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?
sn24.8:3.8.eng: “That which is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, and explored by the mind: is that permanent or impermanent?”

sn24.8:3.10.pli: api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:
sn24.8:3.10.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would such a view arise?”

sn24.8:4.1.pli: “Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa imesu ca ṭhānesu kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti, dukkhepissa kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti …pe… dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāyapissa kaṅkhā pahīnā hoti—
sn24.8:4.1.eng: “When a noble disciple has given up doubt regarding these six grounds, and has given up doubt in suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation,

sn24.8:4.2.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako sotāpanno avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyano”ti.
sn24.8:4.2.eng: they’re called a noble disciple who is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”
